posts.title: Stories from the U.S. Federal Census
posts.text: These stories illuminate how the census is used and shapes our country.

posts.title: Using Maps for Genealogy Research, Part 1: Finding Records
posts.text: Did you know the Library is home to 433,000 sheet maps, and 20,000 books and atlases published between the 16th and 21st centuries? In the first of this five-part series, we review the various ways genealogists can use these maps in their research.

posts.title: Using Maps for Genealogy Research, Part 2: Fire Insurance Maps - Exploring Space and Time
posts.text: Born of necessity, fire insurance maps can be used with other sources to create family histories with color and context. Find out more in this second part of our five-part series of genealogy research.

posts.title: Using Maps for Genealogy Research, Part 3: Place of Origin and Immigration Stories
posts.text: Determining an ancestor's place of origin, and how they arrived in the U.S., is one of the engaging aspects of genealogy research. In this 3rd part of our five-part series, see the role that maps play in that research and follow the story of one immigrant family from Northern Italy to Iron Belt, Wisconsin.

posts.title: Using Maps for Genealogy Research, Part 4: Topographical Maps, and County Maps and Atlases
posts.text: Discover how topography can help inform your research, creating a powerful narrative that can bring the past to life. Part 4 of our five-part series.

posts.title: Using Maps for Genealogy Research, Part 5: Gazetteers and Finding Maps
posts.text: We wrap up our five-part series with a look at the importance of gazetteers in your genealogical search, and a summary detailing how to find the maps at NYPL.

posts.title: Ten Songs about Libraries and Librarians
posts.text: I'm a librarian who plays music, which got me thinking about songs about libraries and librarians.

posts.title: New York Public Library Digitizes 137 Years of New York City Directories
posts.text: New York Public Library is digitizing its collection of New York City Directories, 1786 through 1922/3, serving them free through the NYPL Digital Collections portal. The first batch—1849/50 through 1923—have already been scanned, and the 1786–1848/9 directories are right now being scanned. The whole collection will be going online over the coming months.

posts.title: Genealogy Tips: Searching the Census by Address
posts.text: Ever wondered who lived in your home before you? Or having trouble finding great-grandparents in old census records? If you are so inclined, and want to search the census by address, to see who lived in your American house many moons ago, this post explains how you can do that. Even better, all the information is available online for free. You will need an address...

posts.title: Emigrant City: Two Stories
posts.text: The recently digitized ledgers contain details of 6,400 mortgages held by customers at the bank, between 1851 and 1921, information that, until now, was available only on microfilm.

posts.title: Can You Help Find the Descendants of Seneca Village?
posts.text: Anthropologists Diana Wall, Nan Rothschild, and Cynthia Copeland of the Seneca Village Project want to hear from "anyone who has heard family stories or has other reasons to believe that he or she is a descendant of residents of Seneca Village."

posts.title: Why Your Family Name Was Not Changed at Ellis Island (and One That Was)
posts.text: There is a myth that persists in the field of genealogy, or more accurately, in family lore, that family names were changed at Ellis Island. They were not.
